Adult male (Orchard).description: Orchard Orioles are noticeably smaller than Baltimore Orioles. Male Orchard Orioles are rich chestnut, never bright orange like Baltimore Orioles.

Female (Orchard).description: Female Orchard Orioles never show any orange tones like female Baltimore Orioles. They also have unmarked grayish-yellow backs while female Baltimore Orioles have some streaking on the back.

Adult male.description: Bullock’s Oriole occurs mostly west of the Baltimore Oriole's range, but the two species occasionally hybridize in the Great Plains. Male Bullock’s have orange (not black) faces and a larger white patch in the wings compared to Baltimore Orioles.

Female.description: Female Bullock's Orioles have a whitish belly whereas female Baltimore Orioles have an orangish belly.

Adult male.description: Some people occasionally mistake American Robins for Baltimore Orioles, but robins are thrushes with shorter bills, rounder heads, solid-brown backs, and a more subdued shade of orange on the breast.
